remarks.para: The execution engine provides features for keeping the session alive and for aborting the function stack when it is no longer needed.

Session management must be enabled by setting the ExecutionEngineConfiguration.EnableSessionManagement flag in the configuration file (and is so by default). The session aborting part of session management can be disabled for each as needed.

If aborting is enabled on a ( and the client supports scripting, the function stack will be aborted if the user leaves the page via hyperlink, by refreshing the page, by navigating the history, or by closing the window. The user will be presented with a confirmation message before actually aborting the function stack if the property is set to or (and the page is dirty).
The confirmation message is only available on Internet Explorer 5.0.1 and later and Mozilla/Firefox 1.0 and later.
The session keep alive feature ensures that the function stack and the session will remain valid for as long as the client dislays a that is part of the function stack.

The session management feature use out-of-band communication (XMLHTTP requests or DHTML hidden requests if no XMLHTTP is available) to transmit refresh or abort requests to the server. The "Run ActiveX controls and plugins" and "Script ActiveX controls marked save for scripting" settings must be enabled in Internet Explorer 6 and earlier in order to use XMLHTTP requests. If ActiveX is disallowed, a DHTML hidden request is generated instead. It is recommended to enable the ActiveX settings in an Intranet environment because the XMLHTTP method is more reliable than the DHTML hidden request.
remarks.note: For Internet applications the user might have disabled client scripting and the session timeout setting should reflect the possiblity that no refresh requests are transmitted.
remarks.para:
The generates client script code that will detect (and prevent) a user's attempt to resubmit a page. In case that the client does support scripting, the is able to identify a resubmit and will throw a .
Such resubmits can occur, for instance, if the server's response time is higher than the user's patience, resulting in the user clicking another button on the page. It is also possible that the user navigates backwards through the browser's history. In such an event the user might also try to resubmit a page or, with enabled session management, try to submit to an already aborted function.

In case of the user navigating through the history, he will be presented with the message defined by the property. You should set this property with a message, containing a hyperlink to the start page or a hyperlink that can be used to initialize the current function.

Due to implementation details of the browers, it is not possible to prevent the user from reloading the page from the cache, e.g. by hitting the refresh button (F5 in MS Internet Explorer). If session aborting is enabled, the user will be presented with the option to cancel the refresh. If he does not do so, the function will be aborted and the user will receive an exception on the next submit. It is the application developer's responsibilty to provide a custom error message. This message should contain a hyperlink to the start page or a hyperlink that can be used to initialize the function.

It is possible to disable the page state management by setting the property to and to . In doing so, the application developer takes responsibility of handling resubmits to a page in a meaningful manner. If the execution engine detects an out-of-sequence postback, it will set the flag on the page.
